conversation.content: [shocked] Um, this is, well, completely impossible because you're, [shaky voice], wearing my exact face and even have that, [anxious], scar from when I got caught in the, [nervous], coral reef three years ago. [gasp]
[animated] The scar isn't from coral actually, it's from, [cheerful], trying to exist in your world while maintaining my own, [playful], separate consciousness and memories.
I mean, how long have you been, um, [confused], following me around these dive sites pretending to be, [frustrated], someone else while looking exactly like me? [laugh]
[self-deprecating] Following suggests I have a choice in where I appear, but the truth is, [bitter], I'm drawn to wherever you are like some kind of, [slowly], metaphysical tether I never asked for.
So every certification I've earned, every student I've taught, [hesitantly], you've been somewhere nearby experiencing it too? [sigh]
[warm] Not experiencing exactly, more like, [empathetically], absorbing the emotional residue of your life from a distance.

Well, um, this explains why people keep, [angry], insisting they saw me at places I've never been, like, [passionately], that incident in Bali when I was definitely in California teaching, [very quickly], the advanced rescue course to those firefighters.

Bali was beautiful though, the manta rays were, [excited], absolutely magnificent that day, and I couldn't help but, [apologetic], wonder if you'd have loved them as much as, [whispering], I did in your borrowed form.
[exhausted] Um, so like, do you have your own thoughts or are they just, [sad], echoes of mine somehow? [cough]
[confidently] My thoughts are entirely my own, which is why I'm, [curious], standing here talking to you instead of, [regretful], hiding in the shadows like I usually do. [pause]

[furious] Well, I mean, you've been stealing my identity for years, um, [upset], living some parallel version of my life while I worked so, [crying while speaking], hard to build everything from nothing, you know?
[very sad] Stealing implies I had a choice in being created from, [monotone], your existence in the first place. [groan]
[relieved] Look, I just need to know, um, [quietly], are there more of us out there? [sniffle]
[stern] There's a whole network of doubles, each tied to someone, [mocking], living their 'authentic' life while we exist in the margins, [jealous], desperate for our own purpose beyond reflection.
[mumbling] Um, that's, well, terrifying.

[enunciating every word] I mean, what's truly terrifying is that, um, [very melancholic], some of us are starting to replace our originals when they, [flirtatious], disappear unexpectedly, and nobody ever, [loudly], notices the difference. [chuckle]
[overly polite] Perhaps we could find a way to coexist without, [friendly], this constant shadowing, maybe establish boundaries or territories for each of us. [deep pitch]
Um, boundaries sound nice in theory but, like, [formal], the connection between us transcends physical space and, [sleepily], I'm tired of pretending otherwise. [yawn]
[bored] So, um, what happens now that we've actually met face to, well, [trailing off], face...
Now we both know the truth, which means, [whispering loudly], one of us becomes redundant and nature, [very sincerely], doesn't tolerate redundancy for long.

scenario: A scuba instructor encounters their exact physical double at a remote dive site, leading to an existential confrontation about identity and purpose.
